productDevelopmentLifeCyclePageHeaderDes: Discover the stages in the creation of a product.
productDevelopmentLifeCycleIntro: Developing a successful product involves a structured process that ensures ideas are effectively transformed into market-ready solutions. The product development cycle consists of several key phases: brainstorming, design, testing, and launch. Each phase plays a crucial role in shaping the final product. Here‚Äôs a closer look at each stage of this cycle.
productDevelopmentLifeCycleParagraph1Tex: The development cycle begins with brainstorming. This phase is all about generating ideas and identifying potential solutions to user problems. It involves collaboration among team members, including designers, developers, marketers, and stakeholders. Techniques such as mind mapping, sketching, and collaborative workshops are often used to explore a wide range of ideas. The goal is to gather as many concepts as possible and then refine them into viable product ideas that align with the company‚Äôs goals and market needs.
productDevelopmentLifeCycleParagraph2Tex: Once a promising idea is identified, the design phase begins. This stage involves creating detailed plans and specifications for the product. It includes both User Experience (UX) and User Interface (UI) design. UX design focuses on ensuring the product is intuitive and meets user needs, while UI design concentrates on the product's visual elements. Prototypes and wireframes are developed to visualize the product's structure and functionality. Designers use tools like Sketch, Adobe XD, and Figma to create these visual representations, which will serve as the blueprint for the development phase.
productDevelopmentLifeCycleParagraph3Tex: The testing phase is critical for validating the product‚Äôs design and functionality. Prototypes are tested with real users to gather feedback and identify any usability issues or bugs. This phase often includes several rounds of testing, such as usability testing, A/B testing, and beta testing. Each round of testing provides valuable insights that inform necessary adjustments and refinements to the product. The objective is to ensure the product is user-friendly, functional, and ready for the market. Iteration is key during this phase, as continuous improvements are made based on user feedback.
productDevelopmentLifeCycleParagraph4Tex: The final phase is the product launch. This involves bringing the product to market and making it available to users. A comprehensive launch plan is developed, including marketing strategies, sales plans, and customer support preparations. This phase also includes finalizing the product‚Äôs technical aspects, such as deployment and distribution. Monitoring the product‚Äôs performance post-launch is crucial to address any issues that arise and gather user feedback for future updates. A successful launch is marked by effective communication with users, ensuring they understand the product‚Äôs value and how to use it.
productDevelopmentLifeCycleConclusion: The product development cycle is a systematic process that transforms ideas into market-ready products. By following the phases of brainstorming, design, testing, and launch, teams can create products that effectively meet user needs and achieve business goals. Each phase is integral to the product‚Äôs success, ensuring it is well-conceived, well-designed, thoroughly tested, and effectively launched.
multidisciplinaryTeamsPageHeaderDescript: Get to know the various roles that interact with design.
multidisciplinaryTeamsIntro: UX design is a highly collaborative field where designers typically work in multidisciplinary teams. These individuals often include engineers, researchers, project managers, leads, fellow designers, and others. Multidisciplinary teams come in different shapes and sizes, depending on the organization you work for. But, in general, as a designer, you'll have to collaborate with:
multidisciplinaryTeamsParagraph1Text: They are responsible for translating your designs into functional experiences. They are invaluable when evaluating designs in terms of technical feasibility. Working efficiently with them is an essential step for the successful completion of projects.
multidisciplinaryTeamsParagraph2Text: They aim to understand what users expect from your product. They use methods such as observation, interviews, and surveys to grasp user perspectives. Observations in this regard will help make the best design decisions throughout the process. In small companies or startups, you may be in charge of these research activities, while larger companies have specialized designers in this field.
multidisciplinaryTeamsParagraph3Text: They ensure clear and smooth communication among team members so that deadlines and objectives can be effectively met. They oversee, assist, and take charge of the completion of all tasks planned by team members. They should be seen as the main support source in the face of any unforeseen events or issues.
multidisciplinaryTeamsParagraph4Text: They are responsible for the product's success and communication with stakeholders. They define project goals and delivery deadlines so that other team members can focus solely on their tasks. They are also known as product managers.
multidisciplinaryTeamsParagraph5Text: Often, you won't be the only designer on the project. You'll have fellow designers working alongside you. Collaborating with other designers is a great way to learn.
multidisciplinaryTeamsParagraph6Text: The goal of any company developing digital products is to have a team of individuals specialized in different areas who can collaborate and distribute work in a way that leads to the achievement of set objectives within determined deadlines.
theRoleOfAProductDesignerPageHeaderDescr: Understanding the key specializations on this role.
theRoleOfAProductDesignerPageHeaderTitle: The role of a prodcut designer
theRoleOfAProductDesignerIntro: The field of product design is vast and varied, encompassing several specialized roles that cater to different aspects of the design process. Depending on their skills, interests, and career goals, product designers can pursue various paths, each with its unique focus and responsibilities. Here are five key roles in the product design industry: the generalist, the UX designer, the UI designer, the interaction designer, and the design researcher.
theRoleOfAProductDesignerParagraph1Text: A generalist, often found in smaller teams or startups, handles a broad spectrum of design tasks, from user research and creating personas to designing interfaces and prototyping. Generalists benefit from a wide range of skills and a holistic understanding of the design process, but they might find it challenging to master any one area due to their broad focus.
theRoleOfAProductDesignerParagraph2Text: UX designers focus on ensuring products are easy to use and meet user needs by enhancing usability, accessibility, and overall experience. They conduct user research, create user journeys, and develop prototypes to test and iterate on design solutions. UX designers play a crucial role in shaping the user experience, though the time-consuming nature of research and testing can be a challenge.
theRoleOfAProductDesignerParagraph3Text: UI designers are responsible for the look and feel of the product‚Äôs interface, creating visually appealing and interactive elements. They design layouts, select typography, and maintain design systems. UI designers have a direct impact on the product's visual appeal, but balancing aesthetics with functionality can be difficult.
theRoleOfAProductDesignerParagraph4Text: Interaction designers specialize in designing interactive elements, ensuring smooth and intuitive user interactions. They create prototypes, test features, and collaborate with developers. This role significantly impacts usability and user satisfaction, although staying updated with new technologies and user behavior trends can be demanding.
theRoleOfAProductDesignerParagraph5Text: Design researchers focus on understanding user needs, behaviors, and motivations through various research methods. They provide insights that drive user-centered design decisions, ensuring that products are grounded in real user insights. This role is foundational for creating effective products, but requires strong analytical skills and the ability to communicate findings effectively.
differentBusinessModelsPageHeaderDescrip: Advantages and disadvantages among the different business models for product designers.
differentBusinessModelsIntro: The product design industry encompasses a variety of business types, each offering unique advantages and challenges. Understanding these differences can help designers choose the best path for their careers. Here, we explore the pros and cons of five major business types in the product design sector: startups, large companies, design agencies, advertising agencies, and freelancers.
articleTip1Text: Startups are known for their agility and innovation. Designers in startups often have the freedom to experiment and iterate rapidly, which fosters creativity and quick problem-solving. The dynamic environment allows designers to take on diverse roles, gaining broad experience and skill sets. Additionally, the close-knit nature of startup teams can lead to a strong sense of camaraderie and direct impact on the product.
articleTip2Text: The major drawback is the high level of uncertainty and risk. Startups often operate with limited resources and tight budgets, which can lead to high-pressure situations and job instability. The fast-paced environment might also result in long hours and work-life balance challenges.
articleTip3Text: Large companies offer stability and extensive resources. Designers have access to advanced tools, substantial budgets, and comprehensive market data. Working in a large corporation provides opportunities for specialization and career growth, often accompanied by formal training programs and mentorship.
articleTip4Text: The bureaucratic structure of large companies can slow down the design process. Multiple layers of approval and rigid protocols may stifle creativity and innovation. Designers might also find their roles more narrowly defined, which can limit exposure to different aspects of the design process.
articleTip5Text: Design agencies offer a variety of projects and clients, providing designers with diverse experiences and the opportunity to work on a wide range of products. The collaborative environment fosters creativity and learning from peers. Agencies often emphasize high-quality design and staying current with industry trends.
articleTip6Text: The fast-paced nature of agency work can lead to tight deadlines and high stress. The focus on client satisfaction might require frequent revisions and changes, which can be challenging. Job stability can also be less predictable compared to in-house positions, as agencies rely on a steady stream of clients and projects.
articleTip7Text: Advertising agencies provide designers with opportunities to work on high-visibility campaigns that can significantly impact brand perception. The work is often dynamic and fast-paced, keeping designers engaged and challenged. Collaboration with diverse teams, including marketers and strategists, can broaden a designer's perspective and skills.
articleTip8Text: The primary focus on branding and marketing may limit the scope of product design work, leading to less involvement in the complete product development cycle. The emphasis on meeting client demands and tight deadlines can result in high-pressure situations and potential burnout.
articleTip9Text: Freelancers enjoy the flexibility to choose their projects and clients, offering control over their work-life balance and creative direction. The variety of projects can be enriching, allowing for constant learning and growth. Freelancing can also be financially rewarding, as designers can set their rates and work with multiple clients simultaneously.
articleTip10Text: The biggest challenge for freelancers is the lack of job security and steady income. Finding and retaining clients requires continuous effort in networking and marketing. Freelancers must also manage all aspects of their business, including administration and finances, which can be time-consuming and divert focus from creative work.
productDesignerCompetenciesPageHeaderDes: These are the main competencies a product designer should have.
productDesignerCompetenciesIntro: In the ever-evolving field of product design, professionals must possess a diverse set of skills to create products that are not only functional but also delightful for users. A product designer's role involves blending creativity with technical expertise to solve user problems effectively. Here are the essential skills that every product designer should master to excel in their profession.
productDesignerCompetenciesParagraph1Tex: At the core of product design are UX and UI design skills. UX design focuses on understanding user needs, behaviors, and pain points to create products that provide a seamless and enjoyable experience. This involves conducting user research, creating personas, and mapping out user journeys. UI design, on the other hand, deals with the visual and interactive aspects of the product. A product designer must be proficient in tools like Sketch, Adobe XD, and Figma to create visually appealing and intuitive interfaces that enhance the user experience.
productDesignerCompetenciesParagraph2Tex: Translating ideas into tangible designs is a crucial part of the product design process. Prototyping and wireframing are essential skills that allow designers to visualize and test their concepts before development. Wireframes provide a basic structure, while prototypes bring these wireframes to life, enabling interaction and user testing. Mastery of prototyping tools helps designers iterate quickly and refine their ideas based on user feedback, ensuring the final product is both functional and user-friendly.
productDesignerCompetenciesParagraph3Tex: Product design is inherently collaborative. Designers must work closely with developers, product managers, marketers, and other stakeholders to bring a product to life. Strong communication skills are essential for articulating design concepts, defending design decisions, and integrating feedback from various team members. Effective collaboration ensures that the final product aligns with the broader goals of the team and meets user needs efficiently.
productDesignerCompetenciesParagraph4Tex: Product designers are problem solvers at their core. They must identify user problems and develop innovative solutions through design. This requires critical thinking and a methodical approach to understanding problems, brainstorming ideas, and testing solutions. A successful designer can balance creative intuition with analytical reasoning to create practical and effective designs that address user pain points.
productDesignerCompetenciesParagraph5Tex: The field of product design is dynamic, with new tools, trends, and technologies emerging regularly. A successful product designer must be adaptable and committed to continuous learning. Staying updated with industry trends, attending workshops, and participating in design communities are vital for maintaining a competitive edge. By embracing new knowledge and adapting to changing demands, product designers can consistently deliver innovative and high-quality products that meet evolving user expectations.
productDesignerCompetenciesConclusion: In conclusion, a successful product designer combines UX and UI expertise, prototyping skills, strong communication, problem-solving abilities, and a commitment to continuous learning. By mastering these essential skills, product designers can create products that stand out in the market and provide exceptional user experiences.

Apply for internships or entry-level positions to gain practical experience. Remember, growth isn‚Äôt linear‚Äîit‚Äôs a continuous journey. usabilityTestPageHeaderDescription: Some tips to assist you in this task.
usabilityTestIntro: Usability testing is a crucial step in the product design process, allowing designers to identify usability issues, gather feedback, and iteratively improve the user experience. Here are some tips to ensure your usability tests are effective.
usabilityTestParagraph1Text: Before conducting usability tests, clearly define your objectives and what you hope to learn from the tests. Determine the specific tasks or scenarios you want participants to complete and the metrics you will use to evaluate their performance. Setting clear goals will help you stay focused during the testing process and ensure that you gather relevant insights.
usabilityTestParagraph2Text: To obtain meaningful feedback, recruit a diverse group of participants that represents your target audience. Consider factors such as age, gender, technical expertise, and familiarity with the product domain. Recruiting participants with a range of backgrounds and experiences will help uncover a broader range of usability issues and ensure that your product caters to a diverse user base.
usabilityTestParagraph3Text: Design realistic scenarios or tasks for participants to complete during the usability test. These tasks should reflect typical user interactions with the product and cover a range of functionalities. Avoid leading participants or providing too much guidance, as this may bias their responses. Instead, allow participants to explore the product naturally and observe how they navigate through it.
usabilityTestParagraph4Text: Create a comfortable and non-judgmental environment that encourages participants to provide honest feedback. Assure participants that their opinions are valued and that the goal of the test is to improve the product, not evaluate their performance. Use open-ended questions to prompt participants to share their thoughts, experiences, and any difficulties they encountered while using the product.
usabilityTestParagraph5Text: Usability testing is an iterative process, and it's essential to incorporate feedback into your design iteratively. Analyze the results of each usability test, identify patterns and recurring issues, and prioritize areas for improvement. Make iterative design changes based on the feedback received and conduct additional usability tests to validate the effectiveness of these changes. By continuously iterating and refining your design based on user feedback, you can create a more user-friendly and intuitive product.
lessIsMoreParagraph1Text1: When you face problems in your product, small changes produce better solutions to the problems. When faced with such a situation you must ask yourself, what is the smallest change you could make in order to correct the detected problem?
lessIsMoreParagraph1Text2: Often, people on the team will tend to want to eradicate the problem rather than make a quick fix that will allow the user to stop experiencing it. And it is not that eradicating the problem is a bad decision, but rather that in many cases it requires resources and time that are not available and the problem tends to become entrenched. That is why it is preferable to make a quick solution, that does not require great efforts and that allows that in a few hours or days it is solved, although it is not perfect.
lessIsMoreParagraph1Text3: That is why it is preferable to make a quick solution, that does not require great efforts and that allows that in a few hours or days it is solved, although it is not perfect. In many cases the problem has been dragging on for a long time and correcting it is inevitably something that will cost effort and time, but small modifications can always be made to solve it or reduce it.
lessIsMoreParagraph1Text4: This is the best possible option, which also allows you to work on the perfect solution afterwards. Serious usability problems cannot be ignored. It is always possible to provide a solution that can alleviate it, before being able to design and develop something that eradicates it, that is the idea.
lessIsMoreParagraph2Text1: Modifications require fewer resources and can be carried out quickly. Additionally, they offer more options for implementation. In contrast, redesigning often introduces new problems or situations that were not previously present. Both organizational personnel and users generally prefer the familiar, and redesigning necessitates learning something new.
lessIsMoreParagraph2Text2: Furthermore, redesigning involves making risky decisions and requires bringing together different people within the organization, which can complicate the process. For these reasons, opting for modifications instead of a complete redesign is often a safer and more efficient choice.
lessIsMoreParagraph3Text: It will only require a few tests to prove its effectiveness. You can start by making a very simple and straightforward modification. If it doesn't work as expected, try a more comprehensive modification. If the modification still does not yield the desired results, consider a different approach.
lessIsMoreConclusion: Always examine the consequences of modifications, as there are always repercussions, some of which may be unintended. Remain vigilant in monitoring these outcomes.
designingBasedOnOurThoughtsPageHeaderDes: How to use psychology to make better designs.
designingBasedOnOurThoughtsParagraph1Tex: The brain has more than 20 billion neurons. It is a very complex machine that we have not yet finished understanding, but we already know some things about it. Discover in this article, some of the existing scientific evidence and how to use that information to make better designs.
designingBasedOnOurThoughtsParagraph2Tex: Giving the user too much information at once will produce a feeling of overwhelm that can confuse him in his task. Spreading the information into small pieces that can be digested is often the best option and results in greater user satisfaction. Sometimes it is better if the user has to click more times, if this reduces his need to think and assimilate the information received.
designingBasedOnOurThoughtsParagraph3Tex: Cognitive dissonance appears when two ideas conflict. It is a feeling that causes us stress, controversy and discomfort and the solution is usually to let go of one of the ideas. It also happens that in many occasions we prefer to deny information that opposes a belief, instead of modifying the belief based on the new information. If you want to change your users' minds about something, start by provoking them to make a small change rather than asking them to make a big change or commitment.
designingBasedOnOurThoughtsParagraph4Tex: These are an accumulation of processes, memories and thoughts about how something works that allow us to direct our behavior, allow us to direct our attention and influence the way we solve problems. We use mental models to try to predict the performance of a new app, software we have never interacted with or a sport we have not yet played. We must research our audience, so that we can understand what mental models govern them when they encounter or interact with our product.
designingBasedOnOurThoughtsParagraph5Tex: These are the representations of mental models about a given product. In design it is very important that the mental model and the conceptual model coincide or else the user will not understand the product well and will tend to reject it. Creating positive and useful experiences is largely a matter of understanding the mental model of the users and matching it with the conceptual model you are designing.
mentalModelsPageHeaderDescription: Learn about this concept and some of the best known ones.
mentalModelsIntro: Mental models are applicable schemes that help us to interpret the environment, providing results. There are different mental models applicable to different situations. Users often take some of these mental models when interacting with our products. Knowing these models will help you to empathize with the user and to design in a more user-friendly way. Here are some of these models and their application in product design.
mentalModelsParagraph1Text: What is important is what you can't stop doing, even if the benefit of doing it or the delivery date is not a short deadline. The urgent, on the other hand, is that which demands an immediate response and usually comes from the environment.
articleTip11Text: Focus on the tasks or features that really drive the value of the product. This will help you stay on track and avoid dispersion.
mentalModelsParagraph2Text: Keep a balance between reversible and irreversible decisions. Making reversible decisions makes you move forward faster and you can get a lot of information. However, we must make irreversible decisions so that we don't get stuck somewhere along the way.
articleTip12Text: When designing features or interfaces, consider reversible decisions. For instance, choose a design approach that allows tweaking or rolling back changes without major repercussions. This approach fosters experimentation and learning from mistakes.
mentalModelsParagraph3Text: In order to solve problems more efficiently, we must subject our thinking to an outside perspective. Sometimes, we get caught up in thinking that keeps us circling back to the same idea and we can lose perspective on the real problem or focus energy on something that is irrelevant.
articleTip13Text: Regularly involve users, stakeholders, or usability experts in evaluating your designs. Conduct usability testing, gather feedback, and iterate based on external insights. An external perspective ensures a more holistic and user-centered approach.
mentalModelsParagraph4Text: If something can go wrong, it will. It is not about being pessimistic, but about putting solutions to every situation, so that there is no room for error. This perspective is very helpful, as long as you can visualize the situations that will arise as a consequence of your decisions.
articleTip14Text: Anticipate potential failures or issues. Design robust systems that gracefully handle errors or unexpected scenarios. Consider fallback mechanisms, error messages, and fail-safe features. Murphy's Law reminds us to be prepared for the worst.
mentalModelsParagraph5Text: According to this principle, 20% of your actions produce 80% of your results. It is therefore about acquiring the ability to identify which are the 20% of actions that you must perform in order to achieve the results you set out to achieve.
articleTip15Text: Identify the vital few features or aspects that drive most value for users. Focus your efforts on these critical elements. Prioritize tasks, features, or improvements based on their impact. Pareto's principle guides efficient resource allocation and decision-making.
toolsForSeekingCertainitiesPageHeaderDes: Exploring tools for ensuring certainty in product design.
toolsForSeekingCertainitiesIntro: In the fast-paced world of product design, leveraging the right tools is essential for gaining insights and ensuring certainty in design decisions. From user research to prototyping, various tools empower designers to validate assumptions, test ideas, and create user-centered products. Here are five key tools for ensuring certainty in product design.
toolsForSeekingCertainitiesParagraph1Tex: User interviews and surveys are invaluable tools for gathering qualitative and quantitative data directly from users. By asking open-ended questions and collecting feedback, designers can gain insights into user needs, preferences, and pain points. Conducting user interviews and surveys helps designers understand user behaviors and motivations, allowing them to validate assumptions and identify areas for improvement in the product. Insights gathered from interviews and surveys provide a solid foundation for making informed design decisions and ensuring that the product meets user needs effectively.
toolsForSeekingCertainitiesParagraph2Tex: Usability testing involves observing users as they interact with prototypes or existing products to identify usability issues and gather feedback on design elements. Usability testing allows designers to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of the product's design. By observing user behavior and listening to feedback, designers can identify pain points, usability barriers, and areas of confusion. This information helps prioritize design improvements and ensures a seamless user experience.
toolsForSeekingCertainitiesParagraph3Tex: Prototyping tools enable designers to create interactive prototypes of their designs quickly and efficiently. These tools range from simple wireframing software to advanced prototyping platforms with animation and interaction capabilities. Prototyping tools allow designers to visualize and test their design concepts before investing time and resources in development. By creating interactive prototypes, designers can gather feedback early in the design process, iterate on design solutions, and validate assumptions. Prototypes also facilitate communication with stakeholders, allowing them to visualize the final product and provide meaningful input.
toolsForSeekingCertainitiesParagraph4Tex: Analytics tools track user interactions with the product, providing valuable insights into user behavior, engagement, and preferences. Heatmaps visualize user activity, highlighting areas of interest and interaction on the product interface. Analytics and heatmaps help designers understand how users interact with the product in real-time. By analyzing user data, designers can identify popular features, user pathways, and areas of friction. This information informs design decisions, allowing designers to optimize the user experience and prioritize features based on user needs and preferences.
toolsForSeekingCertainitiesParagraph5Tex: A/B testing platforms enable designers to compare two or more versions of a design to determine which performs better with users. By randomly assigning users to different variations, designers can measure the impact of design changes on user behavior and performance metrics. A/B testing allows designers to make data-driven decisions and optimize design elements based on user feedback. By testing variations of design elements such as layouts, colors, and calls-to-action, designers can identify the most effective design solutions and continuously improve the product iteratively.

cardProjectGeomitesChallenge: Maintain visual and experiential coherence in the game, aligning the work of different disciplines and under a unified design vision.
cardProjectGeomitesToolstack: Figma, Adobe Ilustrator, Adobe Photoshop, Azure DevOps, Miro and DALL-E.
geomitesParagraph1Text: Geomites is a mobile strategy game available on both iOS and Android platforms. The game's core mechanics involve players managing a variety of characters, each with unique abilities and skills, which can be enhanced with items to improve their statistics.
geomitesSubParagraph1Text: Over the past year, I have been part of a dedicated team working to bring this project to life. As the Product Designer, my role encompassed the design of the user interfaces, guided by extensive market research into leading games. Players can level up these characters through two different game modes: online multiplayer battles against other players and an offline story mode that offers progressive challenges.
geomitesSubParagraph2Text: Our team utilized the Agile methodology to ensure a flexible and iterative development process. We structured our work into two-week sprints, each with clearly defined objectives.
geomitesSubParagraph3Text: Geomites is a talented and diverse team, with a single goal of bringing the project to market and making it accessible and enjoyable for as many users as possible.
geomitesParagraph2Text: At this point we reinforce the visual line and the coherence of the project.
geomitesSubParagraph4Text: The visual style of Geomites is characterized by vibrant colors, clean lines, and a cohesive aesthetic that appeals to our target audience. The objective in this point is defining the visual identity of Geomites, ensuring that every element‚Äîfrom characters to environments‚Äîwas visually consistent and appealing.
geomitesSubParagraph5Text: We established a set of design guidelines to ensure uniformity across all user interfaces and game elements. These guidelines covered typography, color schemes, iconography, and layout structures. By adhering to these standards, we created a seamless user experience that felt intuitive and consistent, reinforcing the overall brand identity of Geomites.
geomitesParagraph3Text: Before I started making decisions affecting product design, I went to the market to see what some of the best companies and products that resemble the product Geomites offers were doing and how they were doing it.
geomitesSubParagraph6Text: To ensure Geomites stands out in the competitive mobile gaming market, we conducted an extensive benchmark study of some of the most successful games in the industry. By examining these popular titles, we identified key elements that contribute to their success, such as user engagement, visual design, and gameplay mechanics.
geomitesSubParagraph7Text: From our benchmark study, we extracted several design patterns that were consistently effective across the top games. For instance, the intuitive and user-friendly interfaces of Clash Royale and Brawl Stars highlighted the importance of clear navigation and accessible controls. Archero's engaging progression system and Shakes and Fidget's unique character customization options inspired us to incorporate similar elements into Geomites.
geomitesParagraph4Text: To ensure consistency and efficiency in our design process, we created a comprehensive Figma library. This library included all the design components, such as buttons, icons, color palettes, and typography styles. By using a centralized Figma library, we were able to maintain a cohesive look and feel across all game interfaces.
geomitesSubParagraph8Text: We chose the Greenze typeface to establish a consistent and visually appealing text style throughout Geomites. We chose this typeface for its legibility and compatibility with the adventurous theme of our game.
geomitesSubParagraph9Text: Our colour palette consists of ten colour families: neutral, red, orange, brown, brown, yellow, turquoise, green, violet, blue and pink. These colours have been carefully selected to evoke the adventurous atmosphere of the game and enhance the user interface elements.
geomitesSubParagraph10Text: The project required the icons to have a very good quality and an execution that would allow players to understand the meaning of the concepts they accompany, thus requiring excellent artistic execution.
geomitesSubParagraph11Text: The fortress building allows players to store both their geomites and the items and passives they equip. In this component I designed the building with different tabs and buttons that allow filtered searches.
geomitesSubParagraph12Text: For the implementation, we utilized Figma for design collaboration and React for development. Each sprint began with a review of design goals and priorities. Designs were created and validated using Figma, with input from team members Marc and Aleix. Once designs were finalized, Marc and Aleix led the development process in React, implementing the designs iteratively.

I also got to work closely with a talented team and learned from their skills and ideas. During this project, I improved my skills and learned new ones that will help me in future projects.
